channel.title: Jagex's tech work
channel.description:
Well im wondering why no one talks about jagex's tech work? (or understand)
My assumptions:
[ul][li]No one cares about it, they all just want to hack rs for GP so they can pk all day[/li] [li]Your all to stupid[/li][/ul]

item.title: Jagex's tech work
item.dc:creator: @BAsh BAsh
item.description:
@BAsh wrote:

Speed is always a trade off with memory… but in this case, whatever your goal is, the trade off is stupid.

Read full topic

item.title: Jagex's tech work
item.dc:creator: @light232 light232
item.description:
@light232 wrote:

[quote=“qauters, post:101, topic:298547”][quote author=sppt link=topic=394943.msg2941077#msg2941077 date=1251883669]

what i mean about the “memory leak” is that people never get rid of things, for instance someone might allocate a new object (globably) and use it maybe once or so then just leave it. There is nothing rong with programming things to run as fast as remotely possible, infact thats a +.

You know there’s a garbage collector right?
Also, l2seperate lines properly, it’s a pain in the ass to read what you’re saying
[/quote]
Garbage collecter only works when all references to an object are gone, which is not the case in static / (global when using it from within method only) variables.

Also Killer-99-pkz, prealocating a char array which wastes 320 bytes of memory to make a litle tiny bit of speed profit is the worst idea I’ve ever heard in my whole life. First of all your method without increasing the array is simply useless to release, since string’s max size == Integer.MAX_VALUE. You leak memory which is unacceptable ever, memory is more of an issue in the jvm then cpu speed ever is. So by gaining 1,0E-36% of speed you lost 6,7E-8% of memory on a 512MB pc. Also when making that method usefull for everyone the ammount of money leaked equals the largest string used -.-[/quote]
or you could use softreferences, thus itl get cleanedup when memory is required
http://java.sun.com/j2se/1.4.2/docs/api/java/lang/ref/SoftReference.html

Read full topic

what i mean about the “memory leak” is that people never get rid of things, for instance someone might allocate a new object (globably) and use it maybe once or so then just leave it. There is nothing rong with programming things to run as fast as remotely possible, infact thats a +.

You know there’s a garbage collector right?
Also, l2seperate lines properly, it’s a pain in the ass to read what you’re saying
[/quote]
Garbage collecter only works when all references to an object are gone, which is not the case in static / (global when using it from within method only) variables.[/quote]
I was replying to the part where he said that people create objects but never destroy it

Read full topic

item.title: Jagex's tech work
item.dc:creator: @qauters qauters
item.description:
@qauters wrote:

[quote=“sppt, post:100, topic:298547”][quote author=Killer-99-pkz link=topic=394943.msg2940476#msg2940476 date=1251843472]
what i mean about the “memory leak” is that people never get rid of things, for instance someone might allocate a new object (globably) and use it maybe once or so then just leave it. There is nothing rong with programming things to run as fast as remotely possible, infact thats a +.
[/quote]
You know there’s a garbage collector right?
Also, l2seperate lines properly, it’s a pain in the ass to read what you’re saying[/quote]
Garbage collecter only works when all references to an object are gone, which is not the case in static / (global when using it from within method only) variables.

Also Killer-99-pkz, prealocating a char array which wastes 320 bytes of memory to make a litle tiny bit of speed profit is the worst idea I’ve ever heard in my whole life. First of all your method without increasing the array is simply useless to release, since string’s max size == Integer.MAX_VALUE. You leak memory which is unacceptable ever, memory is more of an issue in the jvm then cpu speed ever is. So by gaining 1,0E-36% of speed you lost 6,7E-8% of memory on a 512MB pc. Also when making that method usefull for everyone the ammount of money leaked equals the largest string used -.-

Read full topic

@sppt wrote:

Killer-99-pkz:

what i mean about the “memory leak” is that people never get rid of things, for instance someone might allocate a new object (globably) and use it maybe once or so then just leave it. There is nothing rong with programming things to run as fast as remotely possible, infact thats a +.

You know there’s a garbage collector right?
Also, l2seperate lines properly, it’s a pain in the ass to read what you’re saying

Read full topic

item.title: Jagex's tech work
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

Killer-99-pkz:

it takes time to allocate new things, moron[br][br][size=1]Posted on: September 01, 2009, 04:20:01 pm[/size][hr]i dont care how fast todays processors are, im talking in large scale. for instance, runescape; it runs at about 50 fps. You have to be smart about your code if your going to run up to that and not be slow. Reallocating a different char array with how many every indecies does not happen in an intant, neither does deallocating. If you just allocate it once then you dont have to worry about it. You need to either shutup or think logicly.[br][br][size=1]Posted on: September 01, 2009, 04:22:54 pm[/size][hr]when you build up all of your shit slow methods it slows down, its only 80 bytes and a few headers for the char array, that is not going to hurt anything. what i mean about the “memory leak” is that people never get rid of things, for instance someone might allocate a new object (globably) and use it maybe once or so then just leave it. There is nothing rong with programming things to run as fast as remotely possible, infact thats a +.

You don’t seem to understand, you are allocating a 180+ byte array and then never getting rid of it for ONE method, and not only that, but a string reverse method that is hardly ever going to be used. You are right, that isn’t much memory, but why don’t we do it to all the methods. Your method also requires the method to only run in a single thread, no concurrency possible at all, and in this world where all new computers have multiple cores, that is a very bad thing.

Read full topic

You have to be smart about your code if your going to run up to that and not be slow. Reallocating a different char array with how many every indecies does not happen in an intant, neither does deallocating. If you just allocate it once then you dont have to worry about it. You need to either shutup or think logicly.[br][br][size=1]Posted on: September 01, 2009, 04:22:54 pm[/size][hr]when you build up all of your shit slow methods it slows down, its only 80 bytes and a few headers for the char array, that is not going to hurt anything. what i mean about the “memory leak” is that people never get rid of things, for instance someone might allocate a new object (globably) and use it maybe once or so then just leave it. There is nothing rong with programming things to run as fast as remotely possible, infact thats a +.

what the fuck? runescape is 50 fps max on any system
maybe you should shut up and think logically
as i said before, be realistic with your biscuit

Read full topic

item.title: Jagex's tech work
item.dc:creator: @the_bank the bank
item.description:
@the_bank wrote:

[quote=“Killer-99-pkz, post:96, topic:298547”][quote author=frank_ link=topic=394943.msg2940560#msg2940560 date=1251847721]

im an ignorant moron that like to rant

runescape isnt hard limited to 50fps, they have that as their target fps
[/quote]
I know, ive been understanding they’re processing part recently (the newer one) i was studying the old one (400 and down (RSC/RS2)) they still have the old processing algorythm in the new client, they try to initialize the one that uses jagmisc.nanoTime then System.nanoTime then the one they used in 400 and down with rs2 and rsc. because java just added System.nanoTime (a few versions ago) so people with lower than the version they added it in can still play. thats what jagex is about, trying to make it as close to 100% comptable as possible[/quote]You’re so wrong it disgusts me. Stop posting for the sake of our health.

Read full topic

item.title: Jagex's tech work
item.dc:creator: @Killer-99-pkz Killer-99-pkz
item.description:
@Killer-99-pkz wrote:

[quote=“frank_, post:93, topic:298547”][quote author=Killer-99-pkz link=topic=394943.msg2940476#msg2940476 date=1251843472]
im an ignorant moron that like to rant
[/quote]
runescape isnt hard limited to 50fps, they have that as their target fps[/quote]
I know, ive been understanding they’re processing part recently (the newer one) i was studying the old one (400 and down (RSC/RS2)) they still have the old processing algorythm in the new client, they try to initialize the one that uses jagmisc.nanoTime then System.nanoTime then the one they used in 400 and down with rs2 and rsc. because java just added System.nanoTime (a few versions ago) so people with lower than the version they added it in can still play. thats what jagex is about, trying to make it as close to 100% comptable as possible

Read full topic

item.title: Jagex's tech work
item.dc:creator: @Jython super_
item.description:
@Jython wrote:

Killer-99… regardless of the value they’re treated as 2-bytes. And actually, they’re treated internally as ints. So you’re wasting 4 * 80 bytes, which is nothing. Weeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeee

Read full topic

item.dc:creator: @Killer-99-pkz Killer-99-pkz
item.description:

[quote=“Nueb35, post:92, topic:298547”][quote author=Killer-99-pkz link=topic=394943.msg2940476#msg2940476 date=1251843472]
when you build up all of your shit slow methods it slows down, its only 80 bytes and a few headers for the char array, that is not going to hurt anything. what i mean about the “memory leak” is that people never get rid of things, for instance someone might allocate a new object (globably) and use it maybe once or so then just leave it. There is nothing rong with programming things to run as fast as remotely possible, infact thats a +.
[/quote]

chars are 2 bytes so its 160 bytes[/quote]
Not if they’re below 128, which all ascii characters are…

160 bytes is still, nothing…

item.title: Jagex's tech work
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

[quote=“qauters, post:89, topic:298547”][quote author=Moparisthebest link=topic=394943.msg2938160#msg2938160 date=1251683858]
First of all, there are no memory leaks in their method, java has a garbage collector that takes care of unallocating memory. As soon as that method exits, the character array is deallocated.
[/quote]
It’s a logical memory leak, since he allocates an static array yet never deletes it will never be deleted! (Until exit of program)[/quote]

Yes, in his method, I said there is no memory leak in sun’s method though.

Read full topic

item.title: Jagex's tech work
item.dc:creator: @qauters qauters
item.description:
@qauters wrote:

Moparisthebest:

First of all, there are no memory leaks in their method, java has a garbage collector that takes care of unallocating memory. As soon as that method exits, the character array is deallocated.

It’s a logical memory leak, since he allocates an static array yet never deletes it will never be deleted! (Until exit of program)

Read full topic

item.title: Jagex's tech work
item.dc:creator: @Jython super_
item.description:
@Jython wrote:

[quote=“pplsuqbawlz_, post:84, topic:298547”][quote author=oksuper_ link=topic=394943.msg2938686#msg2938686 date=1251728063]
Object.dispose() doesnt exist?
[/quote]
oksuper_ don’t be silly:
dispose is an internal method that calls “finalize()” try calling finalize.

On another note I’m glad to see that despite the years that have passed since I have been active, everyone is still incredibly immature.[/quote]

C:\>javap -private java.lang.Object Compiled from "Object.java" public class java.lang.Object{ public java.lang.Object(); private static native void registerNatives(); public final native java.lang.Class getClass(); public native int hashCode(); public boolean equals(java.lang.Object); protected native java.lang.Object clone() throws java.lang.CloneNotSup portedException; public java.lang.String toString(); public final native void notify(); public final native void notifyAll(); public final native void wait(long) throws java.lang.InterruptedExcept ion; public final void wait(long, int) throws java.lang.InterruptedExceptio n; public final void wait() throws java.lang.InterruptedException; protected void finalize() throws java.lang.Throwable; static {}; }

??

Read full topic

item.title: Jagex's tech work
item.dc:creator: @jimmy5410 jimmy5410
item.description:
@jimmy5410 wrote:

abraham2119:

[quote=javadocs]A subclass overrides the finalize method to dispose of system resources or to perform other cleanup.[/quote]

Yes, but you cannot manually call the method, and if you could, calling that method wouldn’t magically remove the object from memory. Only the garbage collector does that.[br][br][size=1]Posted on: August 30, 2009, 08:49:53 pm[/size][hr][quote=“abraham2119, post:79, topic:298547”]edit: hadnt read light’s post. crap… i couldve sworn there was some method that the object class provided to dispose it manually…[/quote]
java.awt.Graphics has a dispose() method that (kinda) does what you’re describing.

[quote=“JavaDocs”]dispose()
Disposes of this graphics context and releases any system resources that it is using.[/quote]

Read full topic

item.title: Jagex's tech work
item.dc:creator: @light232 light232
item.description:
@light232 wrote:

abraham2119:

[quote=javadocs]A subclass overrides the finalize method to dispose of system resources or to perform other cleanup.[/quote]

[quote=“light232, post:77, topic:298547”][quote author=abraham2119 link=topic=394943.msg2938202#msg2938202 date=1251686234]

aaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaand if you are still unhappy with java’s gc, DISPOSE THE OBJECT MANUALLY

object.dispose()

…what?
[/quote]object.dispose() free’s the memory allocated for the respective object instead of depending on the garbage collector to do it for you

edit: what the fuck… i could have sworn object.dispose() existed… anyways, its object.finalize

object.finalize() doesnt do anything…its an empty method…you should override it and object.finalize() is called from the gc when the object is being removed anyway so no need to call it manually[/quote]

Read full topic
